description: From Middle English howe, from Anglo-Norman houe, from Frankish *hauwā (compare Middle Dutch houwe), from Frankish *hauwan (“to hew”), from Proto-Germanic *hawwaną (“to cut, hew”). More at hew.

entries.meaning: An agricultural tool consisting of a long handle with a flat blade fixed perpendicular to it at the end, used for digging rows.
examples: It was obvious that it consisted of several blows to the head from the hoe.

verbs.description: hoe (third-person singular simple present hoes, present participle hoeing, simple past and past participle hoed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To cut, dig, scrape, turn, arrange, or clean, with this tool.
examples: to hoe the earth in a garden
Every year, I hoe my garden for aeration.
I always take a shower after I hoe in my garden.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To clear from weeds, or to loosen or arrange the earth about, with a hoe.
(US, slang) Alternative spelling of ho (“whore, prostitute”).
examples: […]  this chapter  […]  will  […]  explore why pimp (and hoe) characters, with their dramatic staging of gendered and occupational relations […] have taken such hold of the black youth imagination

verbs.description: hoe (third-person singular simple present hoes, present participle hoeing, simple past and past participle hoed)

entries.meaning: (US, slang) Alternative spelling of ho (“to prostitute”).
examples: Pimpin’ came so naturally to MT when he and his sisters played pimp and hoe games that one of his sisters wanted to hoe for him when they grew up.

description: From Middle English hough, hogh, from Old English hōh.

entries.meaning: A piece of land that juts out towards the sea; a promontory.
(Orkney, Shetland) The horned or piked dogfish, Squalus acanthias.
